definition: The physical components of a computer system.
Programs and instructions that control the hardware and perform tasks.
Hardware used to enter data into a computer (e.g. keyboard, mouse, scanner).
Hardware that presents processed data (e.g. monitor, printer, actuator).
External device connected to a computer (e.g. printer, keyboard).
Directs and coordinates operations of the CPU; manages the Fetch‚ÄìDecode‚ÄìExecute cycle.
Stores data, instructions, and parts of the OS currently in use.
Performs arithmetic and logical operations within the CPU.
A small, fast storage location within the CPU used to temporarily hold data or instructions.
Holds the address of the next instruction to be executed.
Stores the memory address of data or an instruction to be accessed.
Temporarily holds data being transferred to or from memory.
Holds the instruction currently being decoded or executed.
Temporarily stores results of arithmetic and logical operations.
A set of parallel wires that carry data, addresses, or control signals between CPU components.
Transfers data between CPU and memory.
Carries the memory address of where data or instructions are located.
Carries control signals like read/write and interrupt requests.
Cycle by which the CPU retrieves, interprets, and executes instructions.
Volatile memory used to store data and programs currently in use. Allows read/write access.
Non-volatile memory containing permanent instructions like the bootstrap loader.
Uses secondary storage as temporary RAM when physical memory is full; slower access.
Stores data and instructions together in one memory space using a single bus (causes bottleneck).
Uses separate memories and buses for data and instructions, allowing concurrent access.
Hybrid of Von Neumann and Harvard; uses cache, pipelining, and multiple cores.
Complex Instruction Set Computer; many complex instructions, slower but easier to program.
Reduced Instruction Set Computer; simple instructions, faster execution, efficient for embedded systems.
Rate of instruction cycles per second, measured in hertz (Hz).
Independent processing units within a CPU that can run instructions simultaneously.
Small, fast memory near CPU storing frequently used instructions/data to improve performance.
Overlapping FDE stages to process multiple instructions simultaneously, increasing throughput.
Using multiple processors or cores to execute tasks simultaneously for higher performance.
A secondary processor dedicated to specific tasks (e.g. GPU for graphics).
Technology allowing one physical core to handle multiple threads simultaneously.
Graphics Processing Unit; performs parallel computations for graphics rendering and AI tasks.
Uses magnetized regions on spinning disks to represent binary data (e.g. HDD).
Uses lasers to read/write data as pits and lands on discs (e.g. CD, DVD).
Uses NAND flash memory chips to store data electronically without moving parts.
Programs designed for end users to perform specific tasks such as word processing, databases, or web browsing.
Software for creating, editing, formatting, and printing text documents (e.g. Microsoft Word, Google Docs).
Used for storing, retrieving, and manipulating structured data (e.g. MySQL, Oracle).
Enables users to access and navigate the web (e.g. Google Chrome, Firefox).
Used to edit and manipulate images and graphics (e.g. Adobe Photoshop, GIMP).
Used to organize, calculate, and analyze numerical data (e.g. Excel, Google Sheets).
Used for creating multimedia presentations (e.g. PowerPoint, Keynote).
Protects the computer from malware, viruses, and other threats (e.g. Norton, McAfee).
Manages and accesses email from multiple providers (e.g. Outlook, Thunderbird).
Used for editing and producing videos (e.g. Adobe Premiere, Final Cut Pro).
Provides tools for developing, testing, and debugging software (e.g. Visual Studio, IntelliJ IDEA).
Creates and runs virtual machines on a single physical computer (e.g. VMware, VirtualBox).
System tools that maintain, analyze, or optimize computer performance, supporting the OS.
Rearranges files on a hard drive to improve efficiency by minimizing empty spaces; improves file access speed.
Allows users to create, rename, move, and delete files (e.g. Windows Explorer, Finder).
Software interface between hardware and OS, enabling communication with devices (e.g. printer driver).
Removes temporary files and junk data to free up storage (e.g. Disk Cleanup, CCleaner).
Protects system from threats like malware or spyware (e.g. Windows Defender).
Software whose source code is freely available for use, modification, and redistribution (e.g. Linux, Apache).
Proprietary software with hidden source code (e.g. Microsoft Windows, Adobe Photoshop).
System software that manages hardware, software, and provides a user interface (e.g. Windows, Linux).
Allows only one user to operate the system at a time.
Allows multiple programs to run simultaneously by allocating processor time to each.
Supports multiple users at the same time using time slices and security controls.
Manages multiple computers working together on a shared task.
A specialized OS designed for dedicated devices; limited and read-only.
Executes tasks within a guaranteed time frame (used in self-driving cars, gaming, booking systems).
Uses icons, windows, and menus; user interacts with mouse or touchscreen.
Offers a list of options for users to choose from (e.g. ATMs, kiosks).
Uses fields for structured data entry (e.g. databases, online forms).
Allows user input in everyday language (e.g. Siri, Alexa).
Reduces file size for storage or transmission (e.g. WinZip).
Create copies of data to prevent loss (e.g. cloud backups).
A signal that temporarily halts the CPU‚Äôs current task to handle an event (e.g. keyboard input).
Software routine executed in response to an interrupt (e.g. timer or network interrupt).
Method for managing CPU time and task execution efficiently.
Each job gets equal processor time slices in a cyclic order.
Jobs are executed in the order they arrive.
Processes are grouped by priority and can move between queues.
Executes shortest tasks first for efficiency.
Runs the process with the least time left (preemptive scheduling).
OS function that handles allocation and deallocation of main memory resources.
Divides memory into fixed-size pages to manage processes; may cause internal fragmentation.
Divides memory into variable-size segments based on logical divisions; may cause external fragmentation.
Uses part of the hard disk as temporary RAM when physical memory is full.
Occurs when excessive swapping between RAM and virtual memory slows the system.
Firmware that performs Power-On Self Test (POST) and loads the OS during startup.
A software-based emulation of a physical computer, allowing multiple OSs to run simultaneously.
Specialized software that allows the OS to communicate with hardware components (e.g. printers, GPUs).

The process of reducing file size to speed up data transfer and save storage space. It improves transmission times and reduces bandwidth usage. Example: compressing images or videos for web streaming.

A compression method that discards some data to significantly reduce file size. It is irreversible and commonly used for media files like MP3s, JPEGs, or streaming video where perfect accuracy is not critical.

A method that compresses data without any loss of information, allowing it to be perfectly restored. Used for text files, databases, and applications where data integrity is essential (e.g., ZIP files).

A simple lossless compression method that replaces consecutive repeating elements with a count and value. Example: 'AAAABBBCCDAA' becomes '4A3B2C1D2A'. Common in bitmap images where pixel colors repeat.

Compression method that replaces recurring sequences with shorter, unique codes stored in a dictionary. Example: Replacing repeated words like 'QuickSort' with a single letter code. Widely used in text and data compression algorithms such as LZ77.

The process of converting readable data (plaintext) into unreadable form (ciphertext) to prevent unauthorized access. Used in secure communication, banking, and data storage. Example: HTTPS encryption when sending web data.
Encryption where the same key is used for both encryption and decryption. It is fast and efficient for large data (e.g., AES) but requires secure key sharing between parties.

Encryption that uses two keys: a public key for encryption and a private key for decryption. More secure but slower. Used in digital signatures, SSL/TLS, and secure communications like banking logins.
A key used in asymmetric encryption to encrypt data. It is shared openly and paired with a private key for decryption.
The secret key in asymmetric encryption used to decrypt data encrypted with the corresponding public key. Must be kept secure by the owner.
A challenge in symmetric encryption where securely transmitting the shared key to both sender and receiver can expose data if intercepted.
A one-way process that converts input data into a fixed-length string (hash digest). Used for data verification and password storage. Example: hashing a password before storing it in a database.
The fixed-size output string generated by a hash function, representing the input data in condensed form.
Message Digest 5 ‚Äî a hashing algorithm producing 128-bit hashes. Fast but insecure due to vulnerability to collisions. Historically used in checksums.
Secure Hash Algorithm 1 ‚Äî creates 160-bit hashes. Previously used in SSL and software verification but now deprecated due to security flaws.
Part of the SHA-2 family ‚Äî generates a 256-bit hash. Commonly used in digital signatures, blockchain, and password protection.
Newest member of the SHA family offering improved resistance to collision and preimage attacks. Suitable for modern cryptographic applications.
Occurs when two different inputs produce the same hash output, reducing hash function reliability. Strong algorithms minimize this risk.
The practice of storing passwords as hash digests instead of plaintext. When users log in, their entered password is hashed and compared with the stored hash. Prevents exposure in data breaches.
Ensuring data remains accurate and unaltered during transfer or storage. Verified using hashing ‚Äî matching hash digests confirm data authenticity.
A data structure using hashing to enable fast data retrieval. Example: using email hash values to quickly find users in a database.
Checking data accuracy using hashing or checksums. For instance, comparing file hashes before and after transmission ensures integrity.
Encryption is reversible (data can be decrypted) and used for confidentiality, while hashing is one-way and used for verification or authentication.
Used for encrypting large files and databases efficiently, where both encryption and decryption are handled by the same entity.
Used for secure communication between parties, digital signatures, and authentication, such as SSL certificates and email encryption.
Used to speed up data lookups. Example: using hash digests of user emails as keys for faster retrieval in hash tables.
The process of verifying that data has not been altered during transmission. Achieved by comparing hash digests before and after transfer.
A metric describing how much a file‚Äôs size is reduced through compression. Example: 4:1 means the compressed file is one-fourth the original size.
The standard markup language for creating web pages and structuring content. Example: <html>...</html> defines the structure of an HTML document.
The root element of an HTML page containing all other tags. Example: <html>...</html>
Contains metadata, title, styles, and links to external resources. Example: <head><title>Home</title></head>
Sets the page title shown in the browser tab. Example: <title>Home</title>
Holds all the visible page content. Example: <body><h1>Welcome</h1></body>
Heading tags used for page titles and section headings. <h1> is largest and <h6> is smallest. Example: <h2>Subheading</h2>
Defines a paragraph. Example: <p>This is a paragraph.</p>
Creates a hyperlink to another page or site. Example: <a href="https://example.com">Visit Site</a>
Displays an image with attributes (src, alt, width/height). Example: <img src="logo.png" alt="Logo" width="100">
Groups elements for styling or scripting. Example: <div class="container"></div>
Collects user input. Example: <form action="/submit" method="post"></form>
Defines input fields. Example: <input type="text" name="user"> (also <input type="submit" value="Send">)
Define unordered (bulleted) and ordered (numbered) lists. Example: <ul><li>Item</li></ul>
Defines an item inside a list. Example: <li>Item</li>
Embeds or links JavaScript. Example: <script>alert("Hi!");</script>
Controls layout, color, and fonts of HTML elements. Example: h1 { color: blue; }
CSS written directly in a tag‚Äôs style attribute. Example: <p style="color:red;">Text</p>
CSS written inside a <style> tag in the <head>. Example: <style>body {background: yellow;}</style>
CSS in a separate file linked to the HTML. Example: <link rel="stylesheet" href="styles.css">
Targets elements sharing a class attribute. Example: .note { color: green; }
Targets a single unique element. Example: #header { background: gray; }
background-color, border-style, border-color, border-width, color (named or hex), font-family, font-size, height, width.
A scripting language for dynamic, interactive web pages. Example: alert("Hello World!");
Reads user input from forms/DOM. Example: let name = document.getElementById("user").value;
Updates page content dynamically. Example: document.getElementById("out").innerHTML = "Hi!";
Writes text directly into the document stream. Example: document.write("Loaded");
Shows a popup message to the user. Example: alert("Hello World!");
Specifies the HTML version. Example: <!DOCTYPE html> (HTML5).
<!DOCTYPE html><html><head><title>Page</title></head><body><h1>Welcome</h1></body></html>
HTML provides structure, CSS adds presentation, and JavaScript enables interactivity‚Äîtogether forming complete web apps.
A group of interconnected computers that share resources, data, and services.
A computer that accesses resources or services provided by a server.
A central computer that manages network resources and services for clients.
A network model where all computers have equal status and share resources directly.
A network model where a central server manages resources and security for connected clients.
Users can share printers, files, and internet access.
Administrators can manage users, permissions, and security from one location.
Data can be backed up centrally at the server.
Requires servers, network cards, and cabling.
Needs skilled professionals to manage.
Connected systems are vulnerable to hackers.
If the server fails, all connected clients may lose access.
Data is divided into packets sent independently across the network and reassembled at the destination.
A dedicated communication path is established for the duration of a connection.
Contains source and destination addresses and sequencing info.
The actual data being transmitted.
Used for error-checking and marking the end of a packet.
A calculated value used to verify data integrity during transmission.
An extra bit added to detect transmission errors (even or odd parity).
Sends bits one after another over a single channel (reliable over long distances).
Sends multiple bits simultaneously using several wires (faster but limited distance).
One-way communication (e.g., keyboard to CPU).
Two-way communication, one direction at a time (e.g., walkie-talkie).
Two-way communication simultaneously (e.g., telephone).
Connects networks and directs data packets based on IP addresses.
Connects devices within a network and forwards data based on MAC addresses.
Connects and filters traffic between two local area networks.
Connects different types of networks and translates protocols.
Strengthens and retransmits weak signals.
Monitors and blocks unauthorized network traffic.
Enables wireless devices to connect to a wired network.
Hardware that allows a computer to connect to a network and assigns a MAC address.
Physical cable used to connect devices in a wired network.
A set of rules governing data communication between devices.
Transfers web pages across the internet.
Secure version of HTTP using encryption (SSL/TLS).
Transfers files between systems.
Ensures reliable, ordered data delivery.
Fast, connectionless transmission ideal for streaming or gaming.
Handles addressing and routing of packets.
Sends emails between mail servers.
Downloads emails from a mail server to a local device.
Allows email synchronization across multiple devices.
Determines which protocol to use based on the application (e.g., HTTP, FTP).
Splits data into packets and ensures reliable delivery using TCP or UDP.
Adds IP addresses for routing packets between devices.
Manages the physical connection and includes MAC addressing.
Harmful software that damages or steals data.
Fraudulent attempts to steal sensitive information via fake emails or websites.
Overwhelms a network with traffic to cause disruption.
Interception and alteration of communication between two parties.
Intruders gaining access to systems or data without permission.
Unauthorized access or disclosure of sensitive data.
Malicious software that locks files until a ransom is paid.
Risks from unsecured wireless networks.
Manipulating people into revealing confidential information.
Encrypts internet activity and hides IP addresses for secure browsing.
Acts as an intermediary to filter and manage network requests.
Translates domain names (like www.example.com) into IP addresses.
Checks local cache for stored IPs before querying servers.
Handles top-level domains like .com, .org.
Holds the official IP address for a domain.
Temporary storage of resolved domain names for faster access.
A system of algebra for variables with two values (0/1, false/true) used to model logical operations and digital circuits.
Binary operator outputting 1 only if both inputs are 1. Truth table: (0,0‚Üí0), (0,1‚Üí0), (1,0‚Üí0), (1,1‚Üí1).
Binary operator outputting 1 if at least one input is 1. Truth table: (0,0‚Üí0), (0,1‚Üí1), (1,0‚Üí1), (1,1‚Üí1).
Binary operator outputting 1 if exactly one input is 1 (not both). Truth table: (0,0‚Üí0), (0,1‚Üí1), (1,0‚Üí1), (1,1‚Üí0).
Unary operator that inverts the input: 0‚Üí1, 1‚Üí0.
NOT-AND; outputs 0 only when both inputs are 1. Truth table: (0,0‚Üí1), (0,1‚Üí1), (1,0‚Üí1), (1,1‚Üí0).
Logical equality: A ‚â° B is true when A and B have the same truth value.
A tabular method listing all input combinations and corresponding output(s) for a logical expression or circuit.
Algebraic form combining variables and operators (e.g., Q = ¬¨A ‚à® (B ‚àß C)); brackets evaluated first.
Gate-level circuit representation corresponding to a Boolean expression; can be translated both ways.
Identify sub-expressions at gate inputs (e.g., (A AND B), (B AND NOT C)) then combine via the output gate (OR): P = (A ‚àß B) ‚à® (B ‚àß ¬¨C).
Real-world rules described with Boolean variables, e.g., valve closes (V) if temperature high (T) OR pressure high (P): V = T ‚à® P.
A visual simplification tool arranging truth values so adjacent cells differ by one bit; used to group 1s and minimize expressions (2‚Äì4 variables commonly).
Apply algebraic laws to reduce expressions (fewer gates/inputs). Example factoring: (¬¨C ‚àß ¬¨D) ‚à® (C ‚àß ¬¨D) = (¬¨D) ‚àß (¬¨C ‚à® C) = ¬¨D.
¬¨(X ‚àß Y)=¬¨X ‚à® ¬¨Y and ¬¨(X ‚à® Y)=¬¨X ‚àß ¬¨Y; used to push negations in/out and change operators.
X ‚àß (Y ‚à® Z) = (X ‚àß Y) ‚à® (X ‚àß Z) and X ‚à® (Y ‚àß Z) = (X ‚à® Y) ‚àß (X ‚à® Z).
The inverse of distribution; factor common terms: (X‚àßY) ‚à® (X‚àßZ) = X ‚àß (Y ‚à® Z).
Regrouping without changing meaning: (X ‚à® Y) ‚à® Z = X ‚à® (Y ‚à® Z), (X ‚àß Y) ‚àß Z = X ‚àß (Y ‚àß Z).
Order of operands does not matter: X ‚à® Y = Y ‚à® X; X ‚àß Y = Y ‚àß X.
X ‚à® (X ‚àß Y) = X and X ‚àß (X ‚à® Y) = X; if X is true the whole term is true (for OR), if X is false the whole term is false (for AND).
Combinational circuit adding two 1-bit inputs A,B. Sum S = A ‚äª B; Carry C = A ‚àß B.
Adds A, B, and carry-in (Cin). Sum S = A ‚äª B ‚äª Cin; Carry-out Cout = (A ‚àß B) ‚à® (Cin ‚àß (A ‚äª B)).
Sequential circuit storing 1 bit; output Q takes input D on the active clock edge (rising edge), holding value until next edge.
Periodic timing signal controlling when state changes occur; D-type changes only on rising edge.

A recursive algorithmic technique that incrementally builds a solution by exploring possible options. If a path is found invalid, the algorithm backtracks to the previous step to try another route. It‚Äôs considered an 'organised brute-force' approach, often used in maze-solving, constraint satisfaction problems like Sudoku, or pathfinding algorithms.

The process of discovering patterns, correlations, or anomalies in large datasets, often from multiple sources (big data). Used in business, marketing, and science to make predictions and identify hidden trends. Example: analysing customer purchase data to recommend products or detect fraudulent activity.

A problem-solving technique that uses experience-based rules or 'educated guesses' to find approximate solutions quickly. Used where an optimal solution would take too long to compute. Examples: used in route planning (A* algorithm), AI decision-making, and NP-hard problems like the Travelling Salesman.

A mathematical or computational approach used to simulate system behaviour under various loads before real-world implementation. Helps predict performance and identify bottlenecks. Used for safety-critical systems (like air traffic control or medical devices) where testing under failure conditions is impractical.

A technique that divides a process into smaller stages executed in parallel, where the output of one stage becomes the input for the next. Commonly used in RISC processors to execute multiple instructions simultaneously during different parts of the Fetch-Decode-Execute cycle. Also used in data processing and manufacturing for efficiency.

The graphical representation of data using charts, graphs, and other visuals to simplify interpretation. Helps identify trends, correlations, and outliers that are difficult to spot in raw data. Used in data analysis dashboards, scientific simulations, and business intelligence reporting.
A named memory location used to store data that can change during runtime.
A named memory location that stores data that remains unchanged throughout program execution.
A variable accessible only within the subroutine where it is created.
A variable accessible from any part of the program.
The section of code where a variable can be accessed.
Defines the kind of value a variable can hold (e.g., integer, string, boolean).
Whole numbers (e.g., 10).
Numbers with decimal points (e.g., 3.14).
A single letter, number, or symbol (e.g., ‚ÄòA‚Äô).
A sequence of characters (e.g., ‚ÄúHello‚Äù).
Data type with only two values: True or False.
A block of code designed to perform a specific task.
A subroutine that performs a task but does not return a value.
A subroutine that performs a task and returns a value.
A variable used to pass data into a subroutine.
The actual value supplied to a parameter when a subroutine is called.
A copy of the data is passed; changes inside the subroutine do not affect the original value.
The address of the data is passed; changes inside the subroutine affect the original value.
Executing statements one after another in order.
Using conditions (e.g., IF statements) to make decisions.
Repeating a set of statements (e.g., FOR, WHILE loops).
Executes a fixed number of times (e.g., FOR loop).
Repeats until a condition is met (e.g., WHILE loop).
Executes code at least once, then checks the condition (not supported in Python).
Perform math operations (+, -, *, /, %, **, //).
Compare values (<, >, ==, !=, <=, >=).
Combine logical conditions (AND, OR, NOT).
Stores multiple items of the same type under one name with fixed size.
Dynamic data structure that can grow or shrink, storing mixed data types.
Immutable sequence of elements; cannot be changed after creation.
Stores multiple related data items (of possibly different types) under one structure.
A collection of multiple records stored in an array.
Joining strings together.
Extracting part of a string using slicing.
Returns string length.
Converts a character to its ASCII code.
Converts ASCII code to a character.
Type conversion functions.
Opens a file with a specific mode (r, w, a).
Opens a file for reading.
Opens a file for writing (overwrites existing file).
Adds data to the end of the file.
Reads the entire file as a string.
Reads one line at a time.
Reads all lines into a list.
Writes data to a file.
Writes a list of strings to a file.
When a function calls itself to solve smaller instances of a problem.
The stopping condition for a recursive function.
Error caused when recursion runs too deep.
Expected valid inputs for testing.
Clearly invalid inputs for testing.
Values on the edge of valid ranges for testing.
Prevents code from running due to incorrect syntax.
Occurs while the program is running.
Program runs but gives incorrect output.
The process of finding and fixing program errors.
Identifies and describes code errors.
Stops execution at specific points to inspect variables.
Color-coding for easy readability of code.
Monitors variable values during execution.
Suggests code as you type.
Runs code line by line for debugging.
Set of rules to make code readable, consistent, and maintainable (naming, indentation, commenting).
A blueprint for creating objects that defines attributes (data) and methods (behaviour).
An instance of a class with specific values for its attributes.
Hiding an object‚Äôs data and allowing controlled access only through methods (getters and setters).
When a child class inherits attributes and methods from a parent class, promoting code reuse.
The ability for methods to take multiple forms (via method overloading or overriding).
Hiding complex implementation details and exposing only essential features.
A function defined inside a class that describes an object‚Äôs behaviour.
A special method automatically called when an object is created; used to initialise attributes.
A method that retrieves the value of an attribute.
A method that updates the value of an attribute.
When a child class redefines a method inherited from the parent class to change its behaviour.
When multiple methods share the same name but have different parameters.
Attributes or methods that can be accessed from anywhere in the program.
Attributes or methods that can only be accessed within the same class.
Attributes or methods that can be accessed within the class and its subclasses.
The class whose features are inherited by another class.
The class that inherits properties and methods from a parent class.
A function used to call methods or constructors from the parent class within a child class.
Protects data from being directly modified, improving security and integrity.
Simplifies complexity by exposing only necessary parts of the code.
Promotes reusability and allows extension of existing code without rewriting.
Enhances flexibility by allowing one interface to be used for multiple data types or actions.
Occurs when a subclass provides a specific implementation of a method that is already defined in its superclass.
Occurs when multiple methods have the same name but differ in parameter type or number.
Methods used to retrieve and update private attributes to maintain encapsulation.
A special method that is automatically called when a new object is created to initialise data attributes.
A fixed-size data structure that stores multiple items of the same data type under one variable name. Each element is accessed using an index starting from 0.
A one-dimensional array stores a list of data in a single line, such as [10, 20, 30, 40]. It allows easy sequential access but has a fixed length.
A two-dimensional array is a collection of rows and columns, similar to a table or matrix. Each element is accessed using two indices, e.g., array[row][column].
An array that can grow or shrink in size during runtime, allowing flexible memory use (as seen in languages like Python with lists).
An array with a fixed size defined at creation time. Memory cannot be adjusted once allocated.
The position of an element in an array or list. Indexing allows direct access to any element (e.g., array[2] retrieves the third item).
The process of visiting and accessing each element in a data structure sequentially, typically using a loop.
Adding a new element into an array at a specific index, which may require shifting elements to make space.
Removing an element from an array, followed by shifting the remaining elements to fill the gap.
Provide fast, direct access using indices and efficient storage for fixed-size collections.
Fixed size; adding or removing elements requires shifting, which can be slow for large arrays.
An ordered, dynamic collection of elements that can store different data types. Lists can grow or shrink as needed, unlike arrays.
Dynamic resizing, can store mixed data types, and supports built-in functions for easy manipulation.
Slower access times compared to arrays due to dynamic memory management and type flexibility.
An ordered, immutable collection of elements. Once created, its elements cannot be modified. Ideal for storing fixed data like coordinates (x, y).
Faster than lists, use less memory, and are immutable for safety and reliability in fixed data storage.
Cannot change, add, or remove items once created, limiting flexibility.
A data structure that stores related fields of possibly different data types under one name, e.g., a student record with name, age, and grade.
An individual piece of data within a record, representing one attribute of an entity (e.g., ‚ÄòName‚Äô or ‚ÄòAge‚Äô).
Data is accessed using field names rather than indices, e.g., student.name or record['Age'].
Allow grouping of related but different data types; easier to understand and maintain structured information.
Cannot perform mathematical operations directly; less efficient for iterative numeric computations.
A data structure that allows modification of its content after creation (e.g., lists, arrays).
A data structure whose content cannot be changed after creation (e.g., tuples, strings).
For i in range(0, length): print(array[i]) ‚Äì accesses each element in order.
student = {Name: 'Alice', Age: 17, Grade: 'A'} ‚Äì demonstrates how different data types can be stored together.
Used in game leaderboards, image pixel storage, or mathematical computations.
Used in databases to represent entities such as employees, students, or customers.
A list that contains other lists as elements, allowing for the representation of multidimensional data.
Arrays are fixed-size and store elements of one type; lists are dynamic and can store multiple data types.
Tuples are immutable and faster; lists are mutable and more flexible.
Records can store mixed data types identified by field names, whereas arrays store elements of the same type using indices.
Arrays enforce uniform data types, improving efficiency, while lists and records allow mixed types for flexibility.
A data structure made up of nodes (vertices) connected by edges. Graphs can represent networks such as roads, social media connections, or computer systems.
A fundamental unit in a graph that represents an entity, such as a city, user, or data point.
A connection between two vertices that shows a relationship or path between them.
A graph where edges have a direction, indicating a one-way relationship (e.g., A ‚Üí B).
A graph where edges have no direction; connections go both ways (e.g., A‚ÄîB).
A graph in which each edge has a numerical weight representing cost, distance, or time.
A graph where all edges are treated equally, without weights.
Two nodes that are directly connected by an edge.
A sequence of connected nodes representing a route from one node to another.
A path that starts and ends at the same node without repeating other nodes along the way.
A graph where there is a path between every pair of vertices.
A graph containing at least two nodes that have no connecting path.
A 2D array representing graph connections; each cell stores 1 or weight if an edge exists, or 0 if not.
A dictionary or list of lists where each key (node) stores a list of its connected nodes. More memory-efficient than a matrix for sparse graphs.
The process of visiting all the nodes in a graph in a specific order to access or search for data.
A traversal algorithm that explores all neighbours of a node before moving to the next level; uses a queue data structure.
A traversal algorithm that explores as far as possible along a branch before backtracking; uses a stack or recursion.
Stores nodes that have been discovered but not yet explored. Ensures level-by-level exploration.
Stores nodes as they are visited; supports last-in, first-out (LIFO) traversal order.
A special type of graph with a hierarchical structure where each node (except the root) has exactly one parent and no cycles exist.
The topmost node in a tree; all other nodes descend from it.
A node directly connected below another node (its parent).
A node that has one or more child nodes connected beneath it.
A node with no children; represents the end of a branch in the tree.
A smaller tree that exists within a larger tree, starting from any node as its root.
A tree where each node has at most two children, commonly referred to as the left and right child.
A binary tree in which every node has either two children or none.
A binary tree where all levels are filled except possibly the last, which is filled from left to right.
A type of binary tree where left child nodes contain smaller values and right child nodes contain larger values than the parent node.
A binary tree where the height difference between left and right subtrees of every node is minimal, improving search efficiency.
The process of visiting each node in a tree in a specific order to access or modify data.
Visits the left subtree, then the root node, and finally the right subtree; used to retrieve sorted data in a BST.
Visits the root node first, followed by the left subtree and then the right subtree; useful for copying a tree.
Visits the left subtree, then the right subtree, and finally the root node; useful for deleting or freeing memory.
The length of the longest path from the root node to a leaf node.
The distance (number of edges) from the root node to a specific node.
Efficient searching, hierarchical data organisation, and fast insertion/deletion in BSTs.
Can become unbalanced, leading to inefficient operations (O(n) time).
All trees are graphs, but not all graphs are trees. Trees have no cycles and exactly one path between any two nodes.
Used in file systems, decision trees, and hierarchical databases.
Used in social networks, web page ranking, and shortest path algorithms like Dijkstra‚Äôs and A*.
The process of applying a mathematical algorithm (hash function) to a key field to transform it into a numerical address where data is stored in a table.
Allows data to be accessed quickly without scanning the entire dataset, ideal for databases and lookup operations.
A data structure that stores key‚Äìvalue pairs. A hashing algorithm calculates the index in the table where each record is stored.
A formula that converts a key into an index in the hash table, such as key mod table size. It determines the storage location for each entry.
The result of applying the hash function, indicating where the record should be stored in the table.
A unique field (like an ID or name) used as input to the hash function to determine where the record is stored.
Hash tables are often implemented using arrays or lists where each index corresponds to a possible storage location.
Strings can be hashed by converting each character to its ASCII value and combining them. Example: 'CAB' ‚Üí (67+65+66) mod 11 = 9.
Python‚Äôs built-in dictionary uses hashing to store key‚Äìvalue pairs for fast retrieval. Example: my_dict['name'] = 'Alice'.

keyword: Search Process in a Hash Table
definition: Apply the hash function to the key, access the resulting index, check for the item, and handle collisions if necessary.
Include creating a table, adding key‚Äìvalue pairs, searching for values, checking for existence, and calculating length.
Occurs when two different keys produce the same hash address and attempt to occupy the same table location.
A collision resolution method where the algorithm checks the next available slot sequentially until it finds an empty one.
A collision resolution method where each hash index stores a linked list of items that share the same hash value.
Indicates how full the hash table is. A high load factor increases the likelihood of collisions and reduces performance.
In the ideal case O(1), but in the worst case with many collisions, performance can degrade to O(n).
Generally O(1), unless frequent collisions occur, which can increase lookup time.
Fast data retrieval and insertion, efficient key-based access, and good scalability for large datasets.
Susceptible to collisions, fixed size if not dynamically resized, and complex to implement compared to arrays or lists.

keyword: Comparison ‚Äì Linked List vs Hash Table
definition: Linked Lists require O(n) for searching; Hash Tables achieve O(1) with good hashing. Hash Tables use index-based storage, while Linked Lists rely on pointers.
Hash tables are used in databases, caches, symbol tables, and programming languages for variable lookup and memory management.
A dynamic data structure made up of nodes connected using pointers. It can grow or shrink during runtime and stores data in non-contiguous memory locations.
A data structure that can change in size as elements are added or removed, unlike arrays which are fixed in size.
A linked list where nodes are arranged in a specific order, such as numerical or alphabetical order.
A linked list where elements are stored in the order they are inserted, without sorting.
A variable that stores the address of another variable or node in memory, linking one node to the next in a linked list.
A special pointer that always points to the first node in the list. Traversal begins here.
A pointer value that indicates the end of a linked list (commonly represented as NULL or None).
A pointer that keeps track of the next available memory location for a new node to be inserted.
A basic building block of a linked list containing two parts: data (the stored value) and a pointer to the next node.
Methods in object-oriented implementations used to access and modify the data and pointer fields of a node safely.
Linked lists are dynamic, non-contiguous, and allow efficient insertion/deletion; arrays are fixed in size, contiguous, and support direct indexing.
Process of inserting a node at the correct position based on value order. Requires traversal and pointer adjustments to maintain order.
Simpler process where new nodes can be inserted at the head or tail without maintaining any order. Fast and flexible for unsorted data.
Creates a new node and links it to the current head, then updates the head pointer to this new node. Efficient with O(1) complexity.
Traverses to the end of the list and adds a new node by updating the last node‚Äôs pointer. Useful in queue-like structures.
Process of removing a node by updating the previous node‚Äôs pointer to skip over it, followed by freeing memory. No shifting required.
Performed using linear search; start at the head and check each node sequentially until the value is found or the end is reached (O(n) time).
The process of visiting each node in a list sequentially to read or manipulate its data, usually starting from the head until NULL.
Dynamic memory use, efficient insertion/deletion operations, and flexible data ordering.
Extra memory overhead for pointers, no random access (must traverse sequentially), and more complex to implement than arrays.
Used in maintaining sorted datasets such as alphabetical name lists or priority queues.
Used in situations where order doesn‚Äôt matter, such as managing recent activity logs or stacks.
Linked lists are used in memory management, undo operations, and dynamic data storage systems.
A structure where elements are arranged sequentially and processed in a specific order, such as stacks and queues.
Allows the structure to grow or shrink as items are added or removed during runtime.
A LIFO (Last In, First Out) data structure where the most recently added element is the first to be removed.
Last In, First Out ‚Äì the most recent item added to the stack is the first to be removed.
A variable that indicates the position of the top element in the stack or the next free slot for insertion.
Adds a new element to the top of the stack. Checks for overflow before insertion.
Removes and returns the element from the top of the stack. Checks for underflow before removal.
Returns the top element of the stack without removing it.
Checks whether the stack has reached its maximum capacity.
Checks whether the stack contains no elements.
Occurs when a push operation is attempted on a full stack.
Occurs when a pop operation is attempted on an empty stack.
1. Check if full. 2. If not, increment top pointer. 3. Insert the new element at the top.
1. Check if empty. 2. If not, remove the top element. 3. Decrement top pointer.
Loops from top to bottom, displaying all elements currently in the stack.
Stacks store previous states, allowing actions to be undone in reverse order (e.g., Ctrl+Z).
A FIFO (First In, First Out) data structure where the first element added is the first to be removed.
First In, First Out ‚Äì items are processed in the same order they were inserted.
Indicates where the next element will be removed in a queue.
Indicates where the next element will be added in a queue.
Adds a new element to the rear of the queue after checking for overflow.
Removes and returns the element at the front of the queue after checking for underflow.
Checks if the queue has reached maximum capacity.
Checks if the queue contains no elements.
A basic queue where insertion happens at the rear and deletion happens at the front. Space can become wasted as elements are removed.
A queue that connects the rear of the array back to the front to reuse freed space efficiently.
If rear = max - 1, wrap around to 0. Insert new item and adjust pointers.
If front = max - 1, wrap around to 0. Remove the item and adjust pointers.
A queue where each element has a priority value. Higher priority items are dequeued first.
Insert elements with priority; remove the element with the highest priority first.
Used in CPU scheduling, network traffic control, and emergency systems.
Stack uses LIFO order; Queue uses FIFO order. Stacks handle reversals; Queues handle sequencing.
Used in recursion, expression evaluation, and call stack management.
Used in buffering, scheduling, and order processing systems.
Both operations are O(1) ‚Äì constant time, as they affect only one end of the stack.
Both are O(1) ‚Äì constant time operations affecting front and rear pointers.
O(n) for both stacks and queues, as traversal is required to locate elements.
A shortest path algorithm that finds the minimum distance between nodes in a weighted graph.
Calculates the shortest path from a starting node to all other nodes.
A graph where each edge has a numerical value (weight) representing distance or cost.
A node whose shortest distance from the start node has been finalised.
A node that has not yet been processed in the algorithm.
The node currently being analysed in the algorithm.
A node directly connected by an edge to the current node.

1. Start with distance 0 for start node, ‚àû for others. 2. Choose node with smallest distance. 3. Update neighbour distances if shorter path found. 4. Mark node as visited. 5. Repeat until destination is visited.
An improvement on Dijkstra‚Äôs algorithm that adds a heuristic to estimate the remaining distance to the goal.
An estimated distance or cost from a node to the final destination.
The total distance travelled from the start node to the current node.
The sum of the actual distance and heuristic: f = g + h.

1. Start at the beginning node. 2. For each neighbour, calculate f = g + h. 3. Add unvisited nodes to open list. 4. Choose node with lowest f value as current. 5. Stop when destination node is reached.
Nodes that are discovered but not yet visited.
Nodes that have been visited and finalised.
Function used to estimate the cost from a node to the goal (e.g., straight-line distance).
The path with the smallest total distance or cost.
A point in a graph representing an entity such as a city or location.
A connection between two nodes representing distance or cost.
A sequence of connected nodes from start to destination.
A collection of nodes and edges representing a network of connections.
Dijkstra: slower, no heuristic, checks all paths. A*: faster, uses heuristic, visits fewer nodes.
Finds the most efficient path to the destination by using both actual and estimated distances.
Helps A* find a solution faster by guiding the search toward the goal.
Used in GPS, network routing, and AI pathfinding systems.
A method used by a computer to find a specific item in a data structure such as an array or list.
Checks each element one by one until the target item is found or the list ends. Works on unsorted lists.
Simple and works on any list; efficient for small datasets.
Inefficient for large lists as it must check each item.
O(N) ‚Äì Linear time.
Efficient search for sorted lists; repeatedly divides the list in half until the target is found.
Very efficient on large, sorted datasets.
Requires the list to be sorted first.
O(log N) ‚Äì Logarithmic time.
A method used to arrange data into a specific order, such as ascending or descending.
Compares and swaps adjacent items repeatedly until the list is sorted.
Simple and easy to implement; useful for small datasets.
Slow for large datasets; performs unnecessary passes even when sorted.
O(N¬≤) ‚Äì Quadratic time.
Builds a sorted list one item at a time by inserting each new item into the correct position.
Fast for small or nearly sorted lists; simple to code.
Inefficient for large datasets; slower than merge sort.
O(N¬≤) ‚Äì Quadratic time.
Uses divide and conquer to split, sort, and merge sublists into one sorted list.
Efficient for large datasets and guarantees O(N log N) performance.
Requires extra memory for temporary sublists.
O(N log N) ‚Äì Linearithmic time.
Uses divide and conquer with a pivot to partition data into smaller sublists which are recursively sorted.
Very fast on average; efficient for large datasets.
Can be inefficient with poor pivot selection; may cause stack overflow.
Best: O(N log N), Average: O(N log N), Worst: O(N¬≤).
Describes algorithm efficiency in terms of time or space as input size increases.
Constant time ‚Äì performance unaffected by input size.
Logarithmic time ‚Äì data size halves with each step (e.g., Binary Search).
Linear time ‚Äì performance decreases proportionally to input size (e.g., Linear Search).
Linearithmic time ‚Äì splits and sorts data efficiently (e.g., Merge Sort).
Quadratic time ‚Äì performance decreases rapidly (e.g., Bubble Sort).
Exponential time ‚Äì doubles with each additional input (e.g., recursive algorithms).
A problem-solving technique that splits data into smaller parts, solves them, and combines results.
A measure of an algorithm‚Äôs efficiency, considering time and memory usage.
The process of removing unnecessary details and focusing only on the essential features of a system or problem.
Identifying common features in problems to create a single solution that can be reused.
Using a function or procedure without needing to know how it works internally.
Representing complex data using simplified data structures while hiding implementation details.
Breaking down a complex problem into smaller, more manageable sub-problems.
Designing a solution by repeatedly breaking a problem into smaller parts, starting from a high-level view.
Data that is entered into a system to be processed.
The results produced by a system after processing input data.
Pre-written code (e.g. functions, modules, classes) that can be reused in multiple programs.
Storing frequently used data in fast memory to improve performance and reduce processing time.
Conditions that must be true before a program or subroutine is executed.
Identifying steps, sub-procedures, and the correct order of operations to solve a problem.
Using logical conditions and decision points to control program flow.
Places in an algorithm where a condition is checked to determine the next action.
A single processor switching between multiple tasks to give the appearance they run at the same time.
A program written in a high-level language by a programmer that cannot run until it is translated.
Low-level (machine) code produced by a translator that the computer can understand.
A complete machine-code program that can be run by the computer without further translation.
Machine-independent code produced by a compiler that must be further interpreted before execution.
A programming language designed to be easy for humans to read and write, using English-like statements.
A machine-specific language that provides direct control of hardware and is harder to read and write.
A translator that converts assembly language into machine code.
A translator that converts the entire source code into machine code in one process, producing an executable file.
A translator that translates and executes source code line by line.
A program that combines compiled object code and library routines into a single executable file.
A part of the operating system that loads an executable program into memory and prepares it for execution.
An organised collection of related data stored so it can be accessed, managed, and updated efficiently.
A structure used to store data in a database, organised into rows (records) and columns (fields).
A complete set of data about one entity, stored as a row in a table.
A single piece of data about an entity, stored as a column in a table.
A field (or combination of fields) that uniquely identifies each record in a table.
The set of valid values that a field is allowed to contain.
Data that contains only a single value in each field (no multiple values in one field).
A database that stores all data in a single table without relationships.
The process of organising data to reduce duplication and improve data integrity.
A table where fields are atomic, field names are unique, records are unique, and a primary key exists.
A table that is already in 1NF and has no partial dependencies.
When a non-key field depends on only part of a composite primary key.
A table that is already in 2NF and has no transitive dependencies.
When a non-key field depends on another non-key field rather than the primary key.
A relationship where one record in a table relates to multiple records in another table.
A relationship where multiple records in one table relate to multiple records in another table, usually resolved using a linking table.
A standard language used to create, retrieve, update, and delete data in relational databases.
An SQL command used to retrieve data from a database table.
An SQL clause used to filter records based on a condition.
An SQL operation that combines data from two tables using a related field.
An SQL command used to add new records to a table.
An SQL command used to modify existing records in a table.
An SQL command used to remove records from a table.
A law that controls how personal data is collected, stored, processed, and shared to protect individuals’ privacy.
A law that makes unauthorised access to computer systems, unauthorised modification of data, and access with intent to commit further crimes illegal.
A law that protects creators’ work by giving them legal rights over how their work is used and distributed.
A law that allows authorities to monitor electronic communications and require access to encrypted data under certain conditions.
Moral concerns about what is right or wrong in the use of computer technology.
The effects of digital technology on society and how people live and interact.
The use of computers and automation in jobs, which can increase efficiency but also lead to job losses and retraining needs.
The use of algorithms to make decisions without human involvement, which can be fast but may be biased or unfair.
Computer systems designed to perform tasks that normally require human intelligence, such as learning or decision making.
When AI systems produce unfair outcomes due to biased data or programmer assumptions.
The effect of computing on the environment, including energy use, e-waste, and resource depletion.
The gap between people who have access to digital technology and those who do not.
The blocking or restricting of access to online content by governments or organisations.
Tracking user activity such as browsing history, location, or communications.
Collecting and processing personal data to identify patterns or make predictions about individuals.
The right of individuals to control how their personal information is collected and used.
The illegal copying or distribution of software, music, films, or other digital content.
Sending threatening, abusive, or harmful messages using digital technologies.
Designing systems so they can be used by people with disabilities or different needs.
The way content is arranged on a screen to improve usability and readability.
The use of colours in design, taking into account cultural meanings and accessibility.
Collections of characters used to represent text, such as Unicode, which supports multiple languages.
A universal character encoding standard that supports text from many languages and cultures.
A linear development model where each stage is completed in order before moving to the next.
An iterative development approach that focuses on flexibility, regular user feedback, and adapting to change.
An agile method that emphasises constant user involvement, pair programming, and high-quality, usable software.
A risk-driven development model that repeats cycles of planning, risk analysis, development, and evaluation.
An iterative method that uses quick prototyping and user feedback to rapidly develop software.
An early, partially working version of a system used to gather user feedback.
A repeated cycle of development used to refine and improve a system.
The participation of end users during development to improve usability and accuracy of requirements.
The process of identifying, assessing, and reducing potential problems during development.
Written descriptions of system design, code, and usage to support maintenance and understanding.
